questions.question_text: Some of these questions have answers that are very similar. Be sure to review all the answers for a question and not just take the first answer that looks correct.

Which image will the following code produce?

from byubit import Bit

def move_paint(bit, color):
    bit.move()
    bit.paint(color)

@Bit.empty_world(5, 3)
def run(bit):
    color = 'blue'
    move_paint(bit, color)
    color = 'green'
    move_paint(bit, 'red')
    move_paint(bit, color)

if __name__ == '__main__':
    run(Bit.new_bit)

Given the following starting world named rgb:

Which block of code will produce the following end result:

answers.answer_html:
from byubit import Bit

@Bit.worlds('rgb')
def run(bit):
    while bit.front_clear():
        bit.move()
        if bit.is_red():
            bit.paint('green')
        elif bit.is_green():
            bit.paint('blue')
        else:
            bit.erase()

if __name__ == '__main__':
    run(Bit.new_bit)

from byubit import Bit

@Bit.worlds('rgb')
def run(bit):
    while bit.front_clear():
        bit.move()
        if bit.is_red():
            bit.paint('green')
        if bit.is_green():
            bit.paint('blue')
        else:
            bit.erase()

if __name__ == '__main__':
    run(Bit.new_bit)

from byubit import Bit

@Bit.worlds('rgb')
def run(bit):
    while bit.front_clear():
        bit.move()
        if bit.is_red():
            bit.paint('green')
        elif bit.is_blue():
            bit.erase()
        else:
            bit.paint('blue')

if __name__ == '__main__':
    run(Bit.new_bit)

from byubit import Bit

@Bit.worlds('rgb')
def run(bit):
    while bit.front_clear():
        bit.move()
        if bit.is_red():
            bit.paint('green')
        elif bit.is_green():
            bit.paint('blue')
        elif bit.is_blue():
            bit.erase()
        else:
            bit.paint('red')

if __name__ == '__main__':
    run(Bit.new_bit)

questions.question_text:
Starting with this world:

Which code snippet produces this result:

answers.answer_html:
from byubit import Bit

@Bit.empty_world(4, 4)
def run(bit):
    while not bit.is_blue():
        while bit.front_clear():
            bit.paint('blue')
            bit.move()
        bit.left()

run(Bit.new_bit)

from byubit import Bit

@Bit.empty_world(4, 4)
def run(bit):
    while not bit.front_clear():
        while bit.front_clear():
            bit.paint('blue')
            bit.move()
        bit.left()

if __name__ == '__main__':
    run(Bit.new_bit)

from byubit import Bit

@Bit.empty_world(4, 4)
def run(bit):
    while not bit.is_blue():
        while bit.front_clear():
            bit.move()
            bit.paint('blue')
        bit.left()

if __name__ == '__main__':
    run(Bit.new_bit)

from byubit import Bit

@Bit.empty_world(4, 4)
def run(bit):
    while not bit.is_blue():
        bit.move()
        bit.paint('blue')
        if not bit.front_clear():
            bit.left()

if __name__ == '__main__':
    run(Bit.new_bit)

questions.question_text:
Bit starts in the following world red_bars:

Which of the following implementations of draw_bar will produce the following result?

from byubit import Bit

def go(bit, color):
    while bit.front_clear():
        bit.move()
        if color is not None:
            bit.paint(color)

def draw_bar(bit):
    pass

@Bit.worlds('red_bars')
def run(bit):
    while bit.front_clear():
        bit.move()
        if bit.is_red():
            draw_bar(bit)

if __name__ == '__main__':
    run(Bit.new_bit)

answers.answer_html:
def draw_bar(bit):
    bit.left()
    go(bit, 'red')
    bit.right()
    bit.right()
    go(bit, None)
    bit.left()

def draw_bar(bit):
    go(bit, 'red')
    bit.left()
    bit.left()
    go(bit, 'red')

def draw_bar(bit):
    bit.left()
    while bit.front_clear():
        go(bit, None)
        bit.left()
        bit.left()
        go(bit, 'red')
        bit.left()

def draw_bar(bit):
    bit.left()
    go(bit, None)
    bit.right()
    bit.right()
    go(bit, 'red')
    bit.left()

questions.question_text:
What does the following code print?

def function1(a):
    return a + 2


def function2(a):
    return function1(a) - 5


def main():
    result = function2(3)
    print(result)

if __name__ == '__main__':
    main()

answers.answer_html: 0
-2
3
1

questions.question_text:
Which block of code could produce the following dialog:

Give me a fruit: pear
Those are fine.
Give me a fruit: banana
Those are fine.
Give me a fruit: apple
I like that!
Goodbye!

answers.answer_html:
def main():
    while True:
        fruit = input('Give me a fruit: ')
        if fruit == 'apple':
            print('I like that!')
            break
        elif fruit == 'durian':
            print('No thank you!')
        else:
            print('Those are fine.')
    print('Goodbye!')

if __name__ == '__main__':
    main()

def main():
    while True:
        fruit = input('Give me a fruit: ')
        if fruit == 'apple':
            print('I like that!')
            return
        else:
            print('Those are fine.')
    print('Goodbye!')

if __name__ == '__main__':
    main()

def main():
    while True:
        fruit = input('Give me a fruit: ')
        if fruit == 'apple':
            print('I like that!')
            break
        elif fruit == 'banana':
            print('Those are ok.')
        else:
            print('Those are fine.')
    print('Goodbye!')

if __name__ == '__main__':
    main()

def main():
    while True:
        fruit = input('Give me a fruit: ')
        if fruit == 'pear':
            print('Those are fine.')
            break
        elif fruit == 'banana':
            print('Those are fine.')
            break
        else:
            print('I like that!')
    print('Goodbye!')

if __name__ == '__main__':
    main()

questions.question_text:
Which of the following dialogs is NOT possible with this code?

def want_pets():
    pets = []
    while True:
        pet = input('What pet do you want? ')
        if pet == '':
            break
        if pet == 'dinosaur':
            print('I want one too!')
        pets.append(pet)
    print(f'You want {len(pets)} pets.')
    if len(pets) > 3:
        print("That's too many!")

if __name__ == '__main__':
    want_pets()

answers.answer_html:
What pet do you want? gerbil
What pet do you want? dinosaur
I want one too!

I want one too!

What pet do you want? 
You want 4 pets.
That's too many!

What pet do you want? 
You want 0 pets.

I want one too!

What pet do you want? 
You want 3 pets.

questions.question_text:
What will the following block of code print?

def loop(numbers):
    for number in numbers:
        if number % 2 == 0:
            print(number)

def dance(fruits):
    for kiwi in fruits:
        print(f'I like {kiwi}')

def main():
    numbers = [1, 4, 5, 8, 9, 12]
    dance(numbers)
    loop(numbers)

if __name__ == '__main__':
    main()

answers.answer_html:

I like 4
I like 5
I like 8
I like 9
I like 12

8

I like 5
I like 9

5

I like {kiwi}
I like {kiwi}

8

questions.question_text:
Consider the following code and output.

def just_keepers(things):
    keepers = []
    for thing in things:
        if keep_it(thing):
            keepers.append(thing)
    return keepers

if __name__ == '__main__':
    stuff = just_keepers([-7, 4, 12, 2, -3])
    print(stuff)

[-7, 12]

Which version of keep_it could be used to produce that output?

answers.answer_html:
def keep_it(thing):
    return thing > 7 or thing < -5

def keep_it(thing):
    return thing > 8 and thing < -6

def keep_it(thing):
    if thing >= 12:
        return True
    elif thing < 0:
        return True
    else:
        return False

def keep_it(thing):
    return thing > -3 or thing < 9

questions.question_text: Match each list pattern with the scenario it serves.

answers.answer_match_left: You want to add an exclamation point to each word in a list.
Eligibility is defined by highest grade, then by earliest application. You want to find the most eligible applicant.
A purchase record has information about the number of items, date, and total purchase price. You want to find the total spent across a batch of purchases.
You have a list of speech transcripts. You want only the speeches that mention prayer.

questions.question_text:
Match each block of code with the pattern it demonstrates:

Code Block A:

def find_optimal_venue(venues):
    optimal = None
    for venue in venues:
        if optimal is None or score(optimal) < score(venue):
            optimal = venue
    return optimal

Code Block B:

def convert_to_metric(mileage_reports):
    new_reports = []
    for origin, destination, miles, time in mileage_reports:
        kilometers = convert_to_km(miles)
        new_reports.append((origin, destination, kilometers, time))
    return new_reports

Code Block C:

def identify_priority_cases(cases):
    priorities = []
    for case in cases:
        if is_priority(case):
            priorities.append(case)
    return priorities

Code Block D:

def count_points(games):
    total = 0
    for game in games:
        team1, team2, team1_points, team2_points, location, date = game
        total = total + team1_points + team2_points
    return total

Consider the following code:

students = [
    ('Wright', 'John', 'economics', 'Oregon'),
    ('Sanchez-Moreno', 'Rosamaria', 'computer science', 'Florida')
]

Which code will loop through a list of student tuples and unpack them into variables?

answers.answer_html:
for last, first, major, state in students:
    print(f'{first} {last} -- {major} major, from {state}')

for every student in students:
    print(f'{student.first} {student.last} -- {student.major} major, from {student.state}')

while True:
    print(f'{first} {last} -- {major} major, from {state}')

for students in last, first, major, state:
    print(f'{first} {last} -- {major} major, from {state}')

questions.question_text:
Consider the following code:

def get_participant():
    first = input('First name: ')
    last = input('Last name: ')
    age = int(input('Age: '))
    if first == '' or last == '' or age < 3:
        return None

    return (first, last, age)

In which of the following cases would this function return None? (Mark all that apply)

answers.answer_html:
First name: Adam
Last name:
Age: 4

First name: 
Last name: de Souza
Age: 5

First name: Preet
Last name: Bharara
Age: 2

First name: Sarah
Last name: Page
Age: 10

questions.question_text:
You need to write a function that gets a person's sandwich toppings.

  • If they ask for onions, you need to say those are out.
  • Otherwise, add the topping to a list of toppings and return the list.

Which of these functions accomplishes this?

answers.answer_html:
def get_toppings():
    toppings = []
    while True:
        topping = input("Topping: ")
        if topping == '':
            break
        if topping == 'onions':
            print('Sorry we are out of onions.')
        else:
            toppings.append(topping)

    return toppings

def get_toppings():
    toppings = []
    while topping != 'onion':
        topping = input("Topping: ")

    if topping == 'onions':
        print('Sorry we are out of onions.')

    toppings.append(topping)

    return toppings

def get_toppings():
    toppings = []
    while True:
        topping = input("Topping: ")
        if topping == '':
            print('Sorry we are out of onions.')
            break

        toppings.append(topping)

    return toppings

def get_toppings():
    while True:
        topping = input("Topping: ")
        if topping is None:
            break
        elif topping == 'onions':
            print('Sorry we are out of onions.')
        else:
            return topping

settings.title: Midterm
settings.description:
Please read and understand the following instructions before taking the midterm.

This is an exam. You are on your honor to treat this exam appropriately. You are not allowed to consult any material or people during this exam.

You have 180 minutes (3 hours) to take this test. Most students will finish in under 90 minutes. If you need an accommodation, contact your instructor.

Prepare your exam space. Find a location where you can work uninterrupted and free from distraction for the full test-taking period. 

You are encouraged to have scratch paper available.

Turn off your phone. Close all applications except your browser, and close all tabs except this one.

To start the test, you will need the passcode start-midterm. Only start the test once you intend to take and complete it.

Good luck!
